text: so this was an error I made uh in my
application I got the screen readers to
read the same text twice not exactly the
same text but the same meaning but with
different
wording uh so I started thinking about
what could I do to make sure I didn't
make this same mistake
again um and for me the
answer to that was quite obvious uh I
wanted to test if I could make large
language models detect my errors
before uh I did let users get
it uh hi my name is hwon I'm a
consultant at Miles I'm a bit about
average interested in
accessibility so the first issue you
have to deal with when you're making uh
automatic test is the setup and getting
the data you need for running your
tests uh I started with using playrite
because that's what I was using to test
my
application uh but soon I found some
issues when uh the response from Clyro
was different from what the screen read
was
getting uh so I had to start think about
where does the screen reader get the
data from and it's from the
accessibility
tree um and P wasn't uh had deprecated
its uh access to the accessibility tree
so I had to change the tooling to get
the data to peper which is
Chrome's tooling for automatic browser
tests uh and there it's quite easily to
get the accessibility
three so my double Tech next
problem
um I got the accessibility tree and
filtered out only the text for the
buttons and the links and sent each one
to chatk and
asked is this text repeating
itself please only answer yes or no and
it worked very well
um so I on it caught all my errors and
on my
uh test on my negative tests it only got
one uh false positive that I didn't
think I will have but that ended up
being a link that was really badly
written so it was in fact an error after
all uh so when this went so well I
started thinking which other features
could I test in this way and two things
uh come to mind
uh links and images both have um context
that you want need to
understand for testing the accessibility
requirements so let's start with
links the first thing I tried was just
the really easy one get all the links
and all the URLs and just send it to
chat and see what happens that didn't
work very
well um
when I started thinking about it a bit
more uh it's two different kind of
issues I was wanting to look for one is
does the link text make sense in
comparison to the site it's goes to and
the other one is is the link text
distinct enough that it makes sense
compared to all the other links on the
page um
so I started with the first one is the I
started with the second one does the
link make sense compared to the other
links on the page um and that went
really really well too uh I just
filtered for all the
links and uh removed the duplicates and
sent it to shat and
asked is some of those
links unclear
or in comparison to each
other um and asked it to answer only no
if all the links was good and yes and a
reason if uh something was
unclear uh I noticed that if I asked it
for a list of links it didn't really
work very well but when you just asked
it to say yes or no and give a reason it
worked very
well um and the other issue
does the link text make sense compared
to where it's going
to for my application all the links are
internal so I made a function that takes
the URL and just tells me a description
of the page it's go to which made the
entire problem really a lot easier so
when I tuned that function a bit and the
the description of the pages and gave
some context of what my application was
it worked very well but this part was
very specific for my application so when
I tried to use it on other applications
it needed quite a lot of tuning to get
to work correct but the other part we're
just sending in the list of links and
asking if the links make sense are
distinctive enough that you can
understand where they're going that
worked very well across all the pages I
tested though so that that was really
good um the other thing I wanted to test
was
images I started with the same approach
just send the image
and the alt text and ask both if the alt
text makes sense and uh if the image
should have an ALT
text and that didn't work at all so
again I had to think about the problem I
split it up in its different
pieces uh for the images that had a text
with it asking chat cap if the alt text
makes sense for the image seems to work
really
well uh it has good understanding if the
both on
icons and on ordinary images if the text
makes
sense uh but one thing it doesn't do uh
very well is the detecting if the image
needs some text at
all uh because it thinks that all images
always needs a descriptive
text uh and that matches quite a lot of
uh opinions on the
internet but I have a different opinion
um it's really dependent on the context
of the image and the text around it
so it mostly went well with images too I
don't have too many of them in my
applications I hav done that much on
it um and this far I have only
used shat K to test a lot of my future
work on this is trying to make it a part
of my build Pipeline and then I do not
want it to
integrate with I do wanted to integrate
over the internet to an third party
service so I'm trying to tune a local
model to do the same
work and I'm trying to learn it how to
see if images need alt
texts that matches my opinion about how
it should
be um
yeah thank you
